articles.headline: Both Parents Are American. The U.S. Says Their Baby Isn’t.
articles.snippet: Same-sex couples who have babies abroad through assisted reproductive technology face a major complication: Their children may not be American.
articles.abstract: Same-sex couples who have babies abroad through assisted reproductive technology face a major complication: Their children may not be American.
articles.lead_paragraph: Update, Aug. 28, 2020: A judge in Atlanta ruled that the child in this case is, in fact, a United States citizen. The ruling stopped short of striking down the State Department policy. Read the judge’s opinion here.

articles.headline: Venezuela’s Opposition Leader Juan Guaidó May Negotiate With Maduro
articles.snippet: Juan Guaidó remains upbeat in public. But he acknowledged in an interview that the opposition’s capacity to operate is hurting.
articles.abstract: Juan Guaidó remains upbeat in public. But he acknowledged in an interview that the opposition’s capacity to operate is hurting.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — It was a daring gambit: Juan Guaidó, Venezuela’s opposition leader, stood by a military base alongside dozens of uniformed officers and political allies, calling for a military uprising against President Nicolás Maduro.

articles.headline: John Walker Lindh, Known as the ‘American Taliban,’ Is Set to Leave Federal Prison This Week
articles.snippet: The release of John Walker Lindh, captured during the invasion of Afghanistan in 2001, is highlighting questions about his reintegration into society.
articles.abstract: The release of John Walker Lindh, captured during the invasion of Afghanistan in 2001, is highlighting questions about his reintegration into society.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

articles.headline: Trump Administration Could Blacklist China’s Hikvision, a Surveillance Firm
articles.snippet: The move against Hikvision would mark another step to counter China’s economic ambitions, and the first time the administration punished a company for China’s detention of Uighurs.
articles.abstract: The move against Hikvision would mark another step to counter China’s economic ambitions, and the first time the administration punished a company for China’s detention of Uighurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is considering limits to a Chinese video surveillance giant’s ability to buy American technology, people familiar with the matter said, the latest attempt to counter Beijing’s global economic ambitions.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Edward Wong

articles.headline: A Pledge to Pay Morehouse College Students’ Debt Prompts Elation, Envy and a Host of Questions
articles.snippet: Robert F. Smith pledged to wipe out the debt of the graduating class at Morehouse College. Now the students are anxiously waiting to hear what happens next.
articles.abstract: Robert F. Smith pledged to wipe out the debt of the graduating class at Morehouse College. Now the students are anxiously waiting to hear what happens next.
articles.lead_paragraph: Days after a billionaire pledged to pay the collective student debt of the entire 2019 Morehouse College graduating class, euphoria was not the only emotion in the air.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch, Alan Blinder and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: A Populist Win Could Dull Europe’s Appetite for Free Trade
articles.snippet: Populists on the left and the right are poised to make significant gains in elections for the European Parliament, possibly complicating trade negotiations with the U.S.
articles.abstract: Populists on the left and the right are poised to make significant gains in elections for the European Parliament, possibly complicating trade negotiations with the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The chlorinated chickens are back. That’s a bad sign for free trade.

articles.headline: Qualcomm Violated Antitrust Laws, U.S. Judge Rules
articles.snippet: A federal judge found that the chip-making giant charged cellphone makers “onerous” fees for the use of its patents. The company said it would appeal the ruling.
articles.abstract: A federal judge found that the chip-making giant charged cellphone makers “onerous” fees for the use of its patents. The company said it would appeal the ruling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Qualcomm abused its position as a giant of the semiconductor industry to harm competition and overcharge cellphone makers, a federal judge has ruled, striking at the heart of the company’s business and sending shock waves through the smartphone industry.
articles.byline: By Don Clark and Michael J. de la Merced
